snippet: A small but growing group of children of the Chinese elite is calling for reform as a leadership change looms, but the exact meaning of “reform” is being debated.
abstract: Private gatherings of the children of China's founding elites in advance of the once-a-decade changeover of Communist Party leadership, are a telling indicator of how even some in the elite are worried about the course the party is charting for China's future; advocates of political change in the country see the gatherings as proof of growing support for deeper reforms, but it is unclear what reform means to the tiny band of political heavyweights (Series: Changing of the Guard).

byline.contributor: Sharon LaFraniere and Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting. Mia Li contributed research.

lead_paragraph: A small but growing group of children of the Chinese elite is calling for reform as a leadership change looms, but the exact meaning of “reform” is being debated.

headline.print_headline: As China Talks Of Change, Fear Rises on Risks
headline.seo: As China Talks of Change, Fear Rises on Risks
headline.main: As China Talks of Change, Fear Rises on the Risks
